quoteFirst: An officer of the _Hartford_ wrote in his private journal: "The order was, to go 'slowly, slowly,' and receive the fire of Fort Morgan. At
quoteLast: the fort opened, having allowed us to get into such short range that we apprehended some snare; in fact, I heard the order passed for our guns to be elevated for fourteen hundred yards some time before one was fired. The calmness of the scene was sublime. No impatience, no irritation, no anxiety, except for the fort to open; and, after it did open, full five minutes elapsed before we answered.
title:
Campfire and Battlefield
An Illustrated History of the Campaigns and Conflicts of the Great Civil War
author: Johnson, Rossiter, 1840-1931; Connor, Selden, 1839-; Gordon, John Brown, 1832-1904; Howard, Henry W. B. (Henry Ward Beecher), 1849-1906; Howard, O. O. (Oliver Otis), 1830-1909; Morgan, John Tyler, 1824-1907; Ridpath, John Clark, 1840-1900

quoteLast: and went through the Lower-field gate to the right. We went on, & turned to the left by the new road to Regent’s Park. The road & scenery is beautiful.
title: The girlhood of Queen Victoria, vol. 1 (of 2)
author: Victoria, Queen of Great Britain, 1819-1901; Esher, Reginald Baliol Brett, Viscount, 1852-1930 [Editor]

quoteFirst: The fleet steamed steadily up the channel, the Tecumseh firing the first shot at 6.47 A.M. The rebels opened upon them from Fort Morgan at
quoteLast: , and the Brooklyn replied, after which the action became general. The Brooklyn now paused, and for good reason--the Tecumseh, near her, careened suddenly and sank almost instantly, having struck and exploded a torpedo; and her gallant commander and nearly all her crew sank with her.
title:
Great Men and Famous Women. Vol. 2
A series of pen and pencil sketches of the lives of more than 200 of the most prominent personages in History
author: Horne, Charles F. (Charles Francis), 1870-1942 [Editor]

quoteLast: the fort opened, having allowed us to get into such short range that we apprehended some snare; in fact, I heard the order passed for our guns to be elevated for fourteen hundred yards some time before one was fired. The calmness of the scene was sublime.
title: Quaint and Historic Forts of North America
author: Hammond, John Martin, 1886-1939

quoteLast: , yesterday evening, Joan of Arc was burned at the stake.
title: Mark Twain's Letters — Complete (1853-1910)

title: Mark Twain's Letters — Volume 4 (1886-1900)
author: Twain, Mark, 1835-1910; Paine, Albert Bigelow, 1861-1937 [Compiler]

quoteFirst: The countries situated to the West are behind us; the Sun only gets there after it has shone upon our meridian. When it is midday in Paris, it is only 11.51 A.M. in London; 11.36 A.M. in Madrid; 11.14 A.M. at Lisbon; 11.12 A.M. at Mogador;
quoteLast: at Quebec; 6.55 A.M. at New York; 5.14 A.M. in Mexico; and so on. The countries situated to the East are, on the contrary, ahead of us.
title: Astronomy for Amateurs
author: Flammarion, Camille, 1842-1925; Welby, Frances A. (Frances Alice), 1862-1947 [Translator]

quoteLast: , yesterday evening, Joan of Arc was burned at the stake.
title: The Entire Project Gutenberg Works of Mark Twain
